title: How many Senate Democrats will vote to confirm Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court?
preds: Ex-post Edit - Post mortem comment Score: Brier: 0.126, Median: 0.376, Accuracy: -0.038. For me, participating in this question is a good example of the difference between the Brier-Median score and the Accuracy score. I got a relatively decent "net Brier" (Brier - Median), but a relatively low Accuracy score compared to the crowd. My Accuracy owes to my relatively low participation rate (15%).  Generally, I try to have a high participation rating. It's a greater challenge and it avoids "sniping" questions (there is some incentive for that for the purpose of gaining on forecasters who have participated for a long time but neglected to update toward the end of the question period), as discussed with @Ken_Barns earlier.  However, this question demonstrates that there can be value (in terms of contributing to the crowd's accuracy) in providing forecasts later in a question's period. In my particular case, I was already participating in the other Supreme Court question so it made sense to join this one as well. But I did not feel I could add much value to the crowd (to some extent due to lack of time) so I avoided it. Yet, after the allegations came out, I saw that I might have an edge on the crowd, which was giving a high chance of >2, which seemed unwarranted given the possibility of an ensuing partisan fight over a large Dem issue (#metoo). The crowd also shifted rather abruptly toward '0', which I was also questioning. So I decided to join the question at that point (although rather late), and indeed, my forecast added value as evidenced by my Brier/Median scores*. Caveat - of course the "Graphs & Stats" crowd view is not the same as the Median.

Misunderstood the graphic I was looking at. It suggests all the Indies will be voting against, but that one Democrat will be voting with - Joe Manchin. The split was 51 / 49 for. So if Joe Manchin changes his mind within 48 hours... Yes as I understand it, this will be the case.

I am not an expert on all of American politics. I follow it, learn things and sometimes forget the stuff I learned. It took me a while to understand the question and do the briefest of research. Mike Pence casts the final vote, and obviously he will vote in support. The Republicans need at least one vote from the Democrats (presuming all the Republicans vote in favour)? Is that right? So based on what I understand. I think all Dems would vote against it as the highest probability for both political and or moral reasons. But as someone stated below, a yes vote would allow them to change their minds within 48 hours. So they might vote tactically to later delay the vote to allow for further time for any damning evidence that might come up? Right or wrong, you can see how the longer the decision is put off the less 'sealed the deal is.' It wouldn't take more than one person to vote yes and change their mind, and, if this was a tactic they were using - that would be all the majority they would allow. I almost wanted to say the Republicans getting one vote would be 50 / 50 split. But I think there is a possibilty they might just vote no as a strong message. Did that make sense?
Manchin is a yes, with chants of shame on you    in the background.
typo error fix.  Only one Dem senator voted for cloture for Kav. https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/410074-manchin-murkowski-break-ranks-on-key-kavanaugh-vote

Based on today's cloture vote where only Manchin voted yes from the Democrats. If Donnelly voted 'no' on the cloture and has previously indicated he was planning to vote 'no' on Kavanaugh, it seems quite unlikely that he will turn around and vote yes. Similarly, if Manchin voted yes on the cloture (i.e. in favor of expediting the vote), it suggests he's made up his mind and his mind is most likely a 'yes' since if he was going to object he would want to delay the vote.
Good arguments for 2 Dem votes here https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/04/politics/kavanaugh-vote-murkowski-collins-flake-trump/index.html
When Heitkamp saw the recent polls, she decided no matter what was her votes, damage has been done. I suspect similar stance from other Dems: they will go down with the ship.
How America was raped....by the GOP

Chris Coon Delaware

Amy Kolbuchar Minnesota
Under estimated "1" as I perceive it is a 30% chance either will vote YES. Minus the indications today of disgust with Trumps unabashed mockery of Dr Ford.

Cutting bucket 2 in half given the dispicable taunting of Ford at political rally.  The potential Dems know what political damage voting for Kav will now cost is much higher to their political career.

Manchin, Heitkamp, Murkowski, and Collins seem to have tied their wagons together. If the FBI investigation doesn't turn up much, and Collins and Murkowski vote yes, then I would expect Manchin and Heitkamp to do the same, and Donnelly might come along too, but I don't see Heitkamp or even Manchin being the deciding vote.
1 week delay and FBI invest. will decrease Dem scabs voting for Kav.
Jeff Flake and Lisa Murkowski doesn't know what will hit them.
Collins(D) is taking meetings with Assault Survivors. That heavily indicates she will vote NO.  Add to that, Donnally is a NO
Donnally will be voting NO, Manchin will likely vote yes.
They must stick together and gain a few GOP

There are also some big questions around how Democrats will vote. There are currently 10 Democrats running for reelection in red states, three of whom voted in favor of the last Trump-appointed Supreme Court justice, Neil Gorsuch: Sens. Joe Donnelly (IN), Heidi Heitkamp (ND), and Joe Manchin (WV). Manchin told reporters Thursday night that he was still undecided after the hearings
https://www.vox.com/2018/9/26/17902190/brett-kavanaugh-confirmation-vote-count-senate

Jeff Flake said he will vote YES, so it seems the GOP are sticking together. So, there are two RINOs left: one from Alaska and one from Maine. It takes both to block confirmation, one defection would need the VP tie breaker, but still pass.
Again, if GOP sticks together, some Dems would defect. If I were a Democrat, I wouldn't start a mob and demand the heads of the defectors. A couple of Dems senators could mean a Senate majority (in case of blue wave) or giving GOP comfortable cushion (if blue wave fizzles). When the Huffington Post attacks the Dems for their performance at the second half of the hearing, I know they already moved on to the next hill.
Previous news of Manchin likely going to vote in line with his constituent's will remains unconfirmed and countered by his office.  https://twitter.com/elainaplott/status/1045478279220797440
Manchin likely going to vote in line with his constituent's will. https://twitter.com/elainaplott/status/1045478279220797440

I don't see any Democrats defecting at this point. They have plenty of political cover, even to say that the process was too rushed, per this 538 article: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-7-senators-who-will-decide-kavanaughs-fate/

The name of the game, contrary to many pundits' opinion, is not about Roe v. Wade, and not even about Judge Kavanaugh, it is about saving the Blue Dogs Democrats in Trump territory. Therefore, the best outcome would be that Republicans don't have enough votes to confirm, thus sparing the Democrats of having to make a choice: vote for Kavanaugh and anger their own base, or not vote for Kavanaugh and anger Trump voters.  With history of Republicans recoiled from bare knuckles fights, that may happen. Let's see how it plays out Thursday.

There are 3 possible situations:
1) The vote happens before the Senate elections - in which case ALL of the Republicans will vote Kavanaugh in and it won't matter what the Democrats vote. In which case I would expect there to be possibly be 1 outlier, but the majority will stick to the "Anti-Trump" party line. 2) The vote happens after the elections AND the Republicans hold the senate my a majority - much similar to the answer above. The Democrats votes will be inconsequential and therefore a few may stray from the party line, but most won't. 3) The vote happens after the election AND Dems win congress/ tie the senate - in this case, absolutely no Democrat will dare vote to confirm Kananaugh. Anyone who did would immediately be disavowed by the party. There is the additional possibility that the recent claims against Kavanaugh by the 2 women (possibly 3 if Mike Avernatti the creepy porn lawyer actually IS representing a third woman) are substantiated in Senate hearings this week. If it were the case that these claims were found to be true, no Democrat would DARE voting to confirm, if the vote even went ahead.

This question will be voided unless Kavanaugh is up for a vote. If he is up for a vote, there's a strong chance Democrats will unite to oppose him in order to retain the narrative that Kavanaugh is a flawed Justice. However, I updated my forecast to increase the likelihood of 2 Dem Senators voting for Kavanaugh because, if Kavanaugh is up for a vote, then Republicans must know he has the support, and therefore he will win, so the Dem votes won't matter. The 2 votes are Kennedy and Heitkamp, who are both incumbents behind in the polls in very "red" states. If they think supporting Kavanaugh could help them win votes, they may do it, and it doesn't seem a big risk for the Democrats because in all likelihood those candidates will lose anyway and it won't affect the caucus unity in the next Congress. This is a fairly specific possible outcome, but it seemed likely enough that I needed to update the possibility of 2 votes. McCaskill has already said she won't support Kavanaugh and Manchin is ahead in polls.
So much of this answer is a guess. Much of this depends on what assessments Democrats from red states are making as to what Senators Collins and Murkowski will do.
Democrats in Red States always pander to republicans.   They just want to desperately stay in office.   Somebody will weenie out and go with state voters on the religious right.

Precedent:
North Dakota's Sen. Heidi Heitkamp, Indiana's Sen. Joe Donnelly and West Virginia's Joe Manchin -- voted for Trump's last Supreme Court nominee, Justice Neil Gorsuch, last year and face re-election in 2018. Likely dissenters:
Manchin and Donnelly will potentially vote to confirm Kavanaugh, while Heitkamp may cite campaign finance or Roe v. Wade and vote 'nay' with the rest of the Dems, although that is to be confirmed. Nelson (Florida) and Tester (Montana) may also choose to support Kavanaugh, being in red states, although Schumer will likely keep them reigned in along party lines. Once it is apparent that the Republicans will win the vote regardless of Dems, which is likely unless Murkowski (Alaska) and/or Collins (Maine) make a public decision soon, it is easier for the Dems to break the party line and not be the deciding vote for the confirmation, thereby lessening blowback.
In conclusion, I expect 2 Dems to vote in favor, likely Manchin and Donnelly, but each senator seems to be 'reviewing the record' until the eleventh hour, likely to gain more leverage for other goals of theirs in other votes. Alternatively, a strictly party-line vote also seems plausible. Current state graphic: https://www.businessinsider.com/brett-kavanaugh-senate-vote-who-will-support-vote-against-2018-7 Recent statements: https://edition.cnn.com/2018/07/10/politics/brett-kavanaugh-senators-whip-list-vote-supreme-court/index.html Pollsters: https://thehill.com/hilltv/what-americas-thinking/398085-pollster-senate-dems-vote-on-kavanaugh-depends-on-schumer

Now the Dems have jinx up an excuse for not to vote for Kavanaugh, I revise to reflect the new play in kabuki theater. However, the Blue Dogs in Trump backyard are keeping quiet. Only the one safe in their backyard bark a lot. So it is hard to know what the Blue Dogs think. 
The old reasoning still applies: if GOPs are united, and it looks like they are, some Dems will be allowed to vote for Kavanaugh. Jeff Flake, who would take any opportunity, including staging his own funeral to stick it to Trump.... oh wait a minute, it was the other Senator, but you get the idea.... Jeff Flake would vote for Kavanaugh because Flake is now livid that he got duped by Feinstein.

Shifting hard toward zero based on both Kavanaugh's testimony and the recent allegations. Seems to me these issues provide cover for democrats in red states to say they gave him a chance but that they can't vote for him. Reminds me of other failed nominations such as Robert Bork or Harriett Meyers when democratic support fell away quickly after the candidate was revealed to have issues.

Updated for recent news on Kavanaugh. It just doesn't seem to me that there's any incentive for Dems in tight races from red states to vote for Kavanaugh, if a vote even happens. If they're going to win in states that Trump won, they'll do it on the backs of female voters and their polling should show that they have no reason to support the nominee in this case.

this is looking like it will be a pure party line vote on the Democrat side.  Both Bernie Sanders and Angus King have expressed concerns about expansion of Presidential power, so it is very unlikely that either of them would vote in favor of Kavanaugh.
Dem will stay with party line especially after some of the damning things that were discovered about Kavanaugh

Not very exact yet, so numbers aren't too precise. Given the nominee is not very popular, it doesn't feel like red-state Dems will be under much pressure to support him. The hearings have not been going particularly well for the candidate and even Dems like Manchin can justify their "No" vote by saying Republicans haven't given enough time and transparency to vet the nominee. I also think 1 is highly unlikely - if Dems are going to break the united front, they'll allow more than 1 to break, which is why 3 seems pretty plausible. If I were to do more work on this question, I'd revisit the recent voting records of the at-risk Dem Senators to see how often they vote with the President. I'd also like to know what the rhetoric has been like in these races to see if the Dem candidate really needs to support Kavanaugh in order to follow through with how they've positioned themselves.
Only WV and SD may swing Due to elections + 2 independents = 4 max
No democrats simply because of the major differences between the parties and the democrats dislike for the man at the top who picked Kavanaugh

There will be a lot of pressure to present a unified front by Dems and resentment over Obama's nomination of Myrick Garland being held up. But WV is Trump Country and Manchin will likely vote for this mostly qualified candidate. Could be one ot two others pressed by the religious right or conservatives in swing states like Ohio and Michigan.
Support for Kavanaugh's confirmation is near Bork levels. Democratic Senators will listen.

Joe Manchin and Heidi Heitkamp need to strongly consider Kavanaugh for their own re-elections. Joe Manchin is very likely. I believe they will vote in his favor. Claire McCaskill is a wildcard, but Missouri is more “Democratic” leaning and after the Eric Greitens debacle is safe-ish. Overall, Senate Democrats in Trump leaning electorates have less incentive to vote for Kananaugh because a) Kavanaugh is being portrayed as far more conservative than Gorsuch and b) the base has become angrier. That is why I’m strengthening the tails toward 0 and 1
I think that the vote will be before the election, and some democrats will feel the need to vote for Kavanaugh if they are to stay in office.
We must not confirm any SCOTUS seats

7 Dem Senators up for re-election in the midterms in Red States. 3 voted for Gorsuch. Republicans do not need any Dems to confirm but could face some hold-outs from GOP Senators with growing anti-Trump sentiment. Would expect similar outcome to Gorsuch, with same Dem Senators in red states voting yes to ready voting record for fall.  Could gain/lose 1-2 due to mid-terms, with close races in Red States causing Dem Senators to vote yes. A clean no vote from all Dems would be difficult with blue wave sentiment still unclear though recent Cohen plea and Manafort verdict could sway Dems to join party members in no vote.

THere is a trend emerging at the grass-roots. In county committees and Tea Party lodges and AFP - ALL of the activist groups are laser focused of SCOTUS politics and Kav is emerging as the litmus test of Obstructionist/Pragmatist labeling. Independents are circling to see who is what on this issue and to capture them you can't be perceived as part of the Uni-Party or the Obstructionists. They're looking for lesser evils.
If any vote FOR Kavanaugh, they should be hung as traitors.

There are five senators that I think are likely to vote for Kavanaugh: McCaskill (MO), Manchin (WV), Donnelly (IN), Heitkamp (ND), and Jones (AL). All four represent states that trump won handily and have been more open to voting with trump than other senators (see link). I don't think they all break ranks but I do think at least two of them will in order to win reelection. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-trump-score/?ex_cid=rrpromo

A pure guess based on information gleaned from the Sunday talk shows and daily / nightly news programs. I believe though, that a few dems will vote to confirm in order to increase their chances for reelection in the midterms.
Unrealistic to expect a pickup of new votes compared to Gorsuch; some Gorsuch voters going against Kavanaugh are possible.
Democratic Senators who are at risk of reelection in Republican states will vote for him.
Chrisp below has it, in my opinion: bipartisanship will endear voters to the Dems who cross the aisle.  Sugar better than vinegar!

The usual suspects are those who voted for Justice Gorsuch. It seems the GOP is unified behind this nomination, and the Dem donors are forewarned that it doesn't worth it to punish those senators who break rank.  My forecast is weighed toward 3, but more favor 4 than 2. The Dems are more vulnerable than it looks and they know that.

On July 9, President Donald Trump nominated Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. Kavanaugh is a federal judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit. He was appointed by former President George W. Bush on February 25, 2006. Since the nomination, Kavanaugh has met with several Republican senators, including Orrin Hatch of Utah, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, and Rand Paul of Kentucky. On July 30, Joe Manchin of West Virginia became the first Democratic senator to meet with Kavanaugh. Sen. Joe Donnelly (D-Ind.) is scheduled to meet with the judge on August 15, and Sen. Heidi Heitkamp (D-N.D.) has said she plans to meet with him as well. Kavanaugh completed a questionnaire for the Senate Judiciary Committee on July 14. The questionnaire asked for details on the judge’s published writings and public statements, recusals, and judicial offices he has held. Kavanaugh was also asked to list the ten most significant litigations he has handled and to write summaries of each case. You can view that list on Ballotpedia here. On August 1, Senate Judiciary Committee Chair Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) said Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearings will likely begin in September. The senator predicted a confirmation vote would happen no later than October.

IF congress goes into full monty raw political mode and scripts every last bit of this out - maybe there really is something in the 1,000,000 document trove that would be republican gold pre election, or some other deal - the bare min needed to pass him will emerge.
Any Democrat voting to Confirm Kavanaugh - will lose their seat and be vilified.
This estimate is based upon the vote happening before the date of the mid-term elections.

They can't stop this happening anyway.  If Schumer were smart he'd take the whip off and let the swing-state and otherwise troubled Ds either vote Yes or abstain or be out of town.  There is no evidence so far that Schumer is smart, but some will probably jump ship anyway.

Joe Manchin, Heidi Heitkamp, and Joe Donnelly are the most likely to vote to confirm Judge Kavanaugh. I think Joe Manchin will only vote no if his no vote is certain to bring down the nomination. Joe Donnelly has the most leeway. If Joe Manchin votes yes, then Heidi Heitkamp will vote yes.

Basing on 51 votes simple majority required; taking into account who has professed to stand against him, counting any red state dem who hasn't come out publicly with a firm "no" as a possible "yes" I come up with about 5 possible. I'm still looking for a better accounting of those undecided and not basing it on any specific issue.  https://www.cnn.com/2018/07/10/politics/brett-kavanaugh-senators-whip-list-vote-supreme-court/index.html
Once Republicans fall in line, and they always do, Manchin, McCaskill, Heitkamp and possibly Donnelly will go for him.

Two Democrat Senators have both ideology and the desire to be reelected as reasons for voting for Kavanaugh.
A couple more might decide that it is going to happen anyway and it would help the reelection chances by voting for Kavanaugh even if he is not their preferred choice for the Court.
